CTags plug-in for Notepad++ NppTags FrankFesevur 2013-07-14
Introduction
NppTags is a Exuberant CTags plug-in for Notepad++.
When you use Notepad++ to program in a popular programming language (like C/C++, Java, JavaScript, PHP), ctags can be very useful for you. It creates a so called tags file that can be used to navigate through your sources. This small tool can help you to jump to a selected function / variable / class / etc in your code by pressing just one key!
Installation Note
For the plug-in to work properly it is important that ctags.exe is somewhere in the path, preferably in the XXXXx.
How to use this plug-in
This plug-in has two different ways to use:
FindTag tries to find the tag (function, variable, etc) under the cursor. If you want to jump to this tag simply press the assigned button. If there is only one reference found, you will be taken to it. Otherwise a dialog is shown where you can select the right one. If the tags is not found in the primary file, it will search the secondary file (as set in the options). Please be aware that the first time this file must be created, and from the root of my compiler's include directory it took more than 30 seconds.
ShowTags shows all (recognized) tags in a tree. You can select a tag from the tree and you will be taken to it.
Tree
Since ctags supports so many programming languages, it is impossible for me to add support for all these languages to the tree instantly.
Based upon a combination of the documentation of ctags and personal testing, these languages should work quite well:
Classic ASP
C / C++
C#
Java
JavaScript
PHP
Python
If your programming language isn't in the list and/or your type of tags don't show (properly) in the tree, contact me because it is not so difficult to add support for other languages/types.
Note that this it only affects the tree, FindTag should not have any problem.
Contact
The plug-in's web page can be found at https://code.google.com/p/npptags/. The downloads and issue tracker can be found there as well. The git repository is at https://github.com/ffes/npptags.
If you have problems with, questions about or suggestions for NppTags and you want to contact me directly, you can send me an email at fesevur@gmail.com.
License
This plug-in is published under the GPL-2 license. See for the full license agreement. You can find the sources of the latest version at the Google code project page or find the lastest developments at GitHub.
This plug-in relies on Exuberant CTags to recognise the tags. Exuberant CTags is released under GPL-2 as well and the source code of Exuberant CTags can be found at its website.
Frequently Asked Questions
Does NppTags recognize tags in language 'XYZ'?
NppTags relies on Exuberant CTags for the recognition of tags. So please check the documentation of Exuberant CTags to see if your language is supported by Exuberant CTags. If not, you have to contact the Exuberant CTags team to see if he wants to add support for your programming language. If Exuberant CTags supports your language the FindTag mode of this add-in should have no problems, but the tree could not show all tags.
How can I use NppTags when the sources are in a directory tree?
There are several ways. When you want to use one tags file for the entire tree, you need to set the Initial Folder of the Tools and set 'Always use full paths in the tags file' in the options.
When you work with only one directory tree, you can set the Initial Folder to a full path.
When you don't want this you could use a Workspace (located in the root of this directory tree) and set the Initial Folder to $WspDir. When you have a workspace loaded, this will put the tags in the same directory where the workspace is located. But if no workspace is loaded, it will work just like $FileDir.
I want to add extra command line options the ctags generates the tags file. Can this be done?
If you want to add extra command line options to ctags, use a ctags.cnf file. See the Files section in the documentation of ctags.
